Fig. 1 Reaction performance of Au/TS-1-B catalyst with different Au loading: (a) conversion, (b) selectivity, (c) PO formation rate, and (d) by-product distribution with and without H2 thermal pretreatment. Note: The data listed were the average values during the DEP reactions within 50 h. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 HAADF images of Au/TS-1-B catalysts with different Au loadings: (a)− (d) before and (e)− (f) after H2 thermal treatment. (a), (e): 0.025 wt.%; (b), (f): 0.05 wt.%; (c), (g): 0.1 wt.%; (d), (h): 0.2 wt.%. Insets are the particle size distribution. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Catalytic performance comparisons of Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst in the DEP reactions conducted at 220 °C following H2 pretreatment at between 250 and 350 °C for 2 h. (a) instantaneous PO formation rate, (b) average by-product selectivity, (c) activation time and deactivation rate, and (d) average value of PO selectivity and formation rate. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of (a) the fresh catalyst, (b) the catalyst after H2 thermal treatment, and the spent catalyst (c) without or (d) with H2 thermal treatment. Insets is the corresponding HRTEM image. (e) The possible dynamic changes in the morphology of Au nanoparticles on the surface of TS-1-B with H2 thermal treatment. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 N 1 s and O 1 s XPS spectra of the Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst: the fresh catalyst, the catalyst after H2 thermal treatment, and the pretreated catalyst after reaction (spent catalyst). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Au 4 f and Ti 2p XPS spectra of the Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst: (a), (b) the fresh catalyst; (c), (d) the catalyst after H2 thermal treatment; (e), (f) the pretreated catalyst after reaction (spent catalyst). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Porous structures of TS-1-B support and fresh and H2-treated catalysts: (a) N2 isotherms, (b) pore size distribution profiles, (c) specific surface areas, and (d) fractal dimensions. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) XRD patterns of the TS-1-B, fresh catalyst, and the H2-treated catalyst. 29Si NMR spectra of the (b) fresh and (d) H2-treated catalyst. (c) NH3-TPD-MS curves of fresh and H2-treated catalysts. RC refers to the relative crystallinity value calculated based on reference [61]. Stable and efficient Au-supported titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1) catalysts are essential for the direct epoxidation of propylene (DEP) using O2 and H2. But the deposition-precipitation method for Au/TS-1 contains low Au capture efficiency and rapid deactivation rate. Herein, Au/TS-1-B (uncalcined TS-1) catalysts were synthesized through a NaBH4 reduction method. The impact of H2-thermal-pretreatment on DEP activities was studied. H2-pretreatment can enhance propylene oxide selectivity, shorten activation time and reduce deactivation rate of catalyst. Organic-templates on the surface of TS-1-B and stabilizers coated on Au-nanoparticles can be partially removed under H2-treatment, thus exposing more active sites for Au and Ti and facilitating their interactions. Furthermore, more porous structures with reduced acid sites and enhanced surface hydrophobicity of pretreated catalyst can promote DEP reaction. Solid stability in TS-1-B, high Au utilization resulting from the reduction method, and favorable modifications through H2-thermal treatment contribute to the exploration of more robust DEP catalyst performance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Au sols DEP reaction H2 thermal pretreatment Deactivation rate Surface configurations Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene oxide (PO), an important propylene derivative, has been widely used to manufacture polyurethane and polyester resins. Thanks to the significant progress in the hydrogen production industry, direct epoxidation of propylene (DEP) in the presence of H2 and O2 has been proven to be a more sustainable and lower cost synthesis route compared to the traditional chlorohydrin and organic hydroperoxide processes [1–3]. The generation of hydrogen peroxide from H2 and O2 on the surface of metal nanoparticles and the further epoxidation of propylene via Ti-containing supports are considered as the primary reaction mechanism pathways for DEP reactions [4,5]. Au nanoparticles supported by titanium silicalite molecular sieves (i.e., TS-1) exhibited favorable PO selectivity and a relatively high PO formation rate [6,7]. However, the exorbitant catalyst cost and the poor catalytic stability significantly restrain the utilization of Au/TS-1 catalysts. Therefore, it is of prime scientific and industrial importance to design a highly efficient Au/TS-1 catalyst and to tune the reaction environments for a significant improvement in catalytic effectiveness and long-term stability. Changes in the Au loading method and amount deposited onto the TS-1 support may affect the microstructural characteristics and surface properties, which further influence the catalytic activity [8,9]. A controllable method with low loading would generally produce Au nanoparticles with small and uniform particle sizes. Particles with sizes that range between 2 and 5 nm are considered a desirable metal loading result [10,11]. The incipient wetness impregnation method has been widely reported for preparing Au/TS-1 catalysts with low metal loading. Nevertheless, this method also suffers from large Au particles with poor uniformity due to the uncontrollable drying procedure and the influence of residual chlorine in the catalyst [12,13]. In contrast, deposition precipitation (DP) and sol immobilization (SI) are considered as better alternatives to reduce the Au particle aggregation issues. These approaches employ a controllable deposition process for the aqueous Au precursors by using various alkalis, carbonates, or reductants, which can produce tiny and uniform Au nanoparticles with sizes of less than 5 nm [14–16]. As for the Au capture efficiency, which is defined as the ratio of the deposited Au components and the total consumed Au precursors, the DP method has consistently produced an unsatisfactory result of less than 20% [17,18] compared to that of the SI method, leading to a significant amount of waste that is unacceptable for future commercialization. The structure and property of the TS-1 support may also greatly influence the catalyst performance in the DEP reactions. The dimension of microporous channel of TS-1 is about 0.55 nm, which could restrict the migration and agglomeration of Au nanoparticles during the loading process, resulting in a smaller particle size [19–21]. These tiny pores likely lead to an increase in the mass transfer resistance. Moreover, the active sites inside the pores are relatively difficult to be accessed, which may favor carbon deposition and rapid deactivation. Xu et al. [22] synthesized a tiny version of TS-1 by adjusting the amount of TPAOH, which enabled an enhanced mass transfer process during the reactions. Feng et al. [23,24] prepared mesoporous TS-1 (MTS-1) and uncalcined TS-1 with blocked internal pores (TS-1-B) through the optimization of template agents, displaying the advantages in resisting coking and improving the utilization efficiency of active metals. In addition, the presence of residual template agents in TS-1-B increased the isoelectric points, which were beneficial for capturing Au nanoparticles by supports. Given the aforementioned advantages, the TS-1-B supports have gradually become an attractive subject in the research of DEP reactions. Several works have studied the influence of various pretreatments to the intrinsic properties of the active sites in the DEP catalysts. The variations in the particle size and oxidation state of the active metals [25–27] and the changes in the surface properties and pore structures of the supports during the DEP reactions [28,29] would result in a slow activation and a rapid deactivation period. For a more extended stable-plateau period of catalytic activity with a higher commercial value, the regulation of the pretreatment process is essential to optimize and maintain the intrinsic activities. A study by Yang et al. [27] suggested that oxygen treatment could promote the formation of Au and reactive oxygen species on its surface, thereby catalyzing the formation of more PO products. Lin et al. [30] found that prolonging the H2 pretreatment time was beneficial to increase the Au0 proportion in the catalyst, which improved the catalytic effect. Ren et al. [31] further studied the effect of mixed gas pretreatment. They reported that Au/TS-1 pretreated with H2-C3H6 was beneficial for the formation and desorption of PO due to the decrease in the average particle sizes of the active metals and the enhanced hydrophobicity of the support surfaces. The differences can be mainly ascribed to the variations of the active components and their relatively complex evolutions since most of the catalysts in previous study was prepared via the DP method. In contrast, the active components in the DEP catalyst prepared via the SI method were only present in a single phase, the intrinsic activities of which were simpler to be manipulated [11,32,33]. However, limited literature exists regarding the amalgamation of the high Au capture efficiency offered by the SI method and the stability advantages associated with the utilization of non-calcined TS-1-B supports. Exploring the combination of these factors could pave the way for a versatile approach in investigating novel catalysts for DEP reactions. Furthermore, it is essential to consider appropriate pretreatments for this type of catalyst, as the SI method itself presents drawbacks in terms of catalytic activity. Herein, we investigated the influence of H2 pretreatment on the Au/TS-1-B catalyst prepared by SI method in DEP reaction. Changes in the reaction performance of the prepared catalysts with different Au loading with or without the H2 pretreatment were compared to optimize the catalytic efficiency. In addition, the compositions and structure variations of active metals and supports were analyzed using multiple advanced characterization methods to determine the role of H2 pretreatment in promoting the DEP reactions and enhancing the catalytic stability. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis of the TS-1-B The TS-1-B was synthesized through the modified process as previously listed in literature [7,34]. In a typical synthesis, 30 mL of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide solution (TPAOH, 25 wt.%) was mixed with 50 g of ultrapure water. Subsequently, 50.0 mL of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, 99.0 wt.%) was added dropwise over 2 h. The mixture was then heated to 80 °C for hydrolysis. In parallel, 1.526 g of titanium (IV) tetrabutoxide (TBOT, 99.0 wt.%) was dispersed into 20 mL of isopropanol (IPA, 99.7 wt.%), followed by adding 5.0 mL of TPAOH into the solution under stirring for 2 h. The obtained Ti-containing solution was slowly dropped into the prepared Si solution, and then the mixture was maintained at 80 °C for 2 h to evaporate alcohols. The as-synthesized solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and then heated inside an oven at 170 °C for 24 h under autogenous pressure. The obtained crystalline solid was washed sufficiently and dried at 100 °C overnight to obtain the TS-1-B powder. 2.2 Preparation of the Au/TS-1-B catalysts Au/TS-1-B catalysts were prepared by the enhanced sol-immobilization (SI) method using NaBH4 as the reducing agent. In detail, to prepare 0.1 wt.% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, 1 g of polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, 99.0 wt.%, K30, 58000) and 1 g of TS-1-B were added into 96 mL of HAuCl4 solution (53.1 μM) under stirring for 30 min, followed by slow addition of freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (3.325 mM) under vigorous stirring for 1 h (pH changes within 7–8). The product was filtered and washed thoroughly before drying overnight at 60 °C under a vacuum atmosphere. The preparation process of other catalysts was identical except for the difference in HAuCl4 solution concentration. The obtained catalyst was named Au(x)/TS-1-B, where x = 0.025–0.2, referring to the theoretical concentration of Au (0.025–0.2 wt.%) in the prepared catalyst. The actual Au content in prepared catalysts was determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES: 720es, Agilent, USA). 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The DEP reactions were carried out in a quartz tubular reactor (inner diameter of 10 mm) using 0.1 g of prepared catalyst (80–100 mesh size). The catalyst was well dispersed onto ∼10 g of quartz sands (50–100 mesh). Scheme 1 shows the schematic illustration of the reaction system. The reaction system temperature was measured in the middle of the loaded catalysts using a specialized thermocouple. For the pretreatment process of Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the catalyst-bed temperature was heated to 300 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C·min−1 and then maintained for 2 h under an H2 atmosphere. Then the system was cooled to the reaction temperature of 220 °C at a cooling rate of 2 °C·min−1. The H2 flow rate was maintained at 14 mL·min−1 during the pretreatment process. Upon reaching the reaction temperature, the feed gas flow to the reaction system was switched on. The ratio of feed gas concentration (C3H6/O2/H2/N2) was adjusted to 1/1/1/7 vol.% with an appropriate space velocity (12000 mL·gcat −1·h−1). After a continuous operation for more than 50 h, the reaction system was gradually cooled down while feed gas flow was maintained before collecting the residual catalysts for further analysis. For the reaction system without pretreatment, the catalyst-bed was heated to the reaction temperature directly in the presence of feed gas. The concentrations of reactants and products were analyzed online using a gas chromatograph (GC-8860, Agilent) equipped with FID (HP-PLOT Q column) and TCD (TDX-01 column) detectors, respectively. The reaction by-products are water (H2O), acetaldehyde (AA), propylaldehyde (PA), acrolein (AL), acetone (AO), propane (PP), and carbon dioxide (CO2). The selectivity, conversion, and PO formation rate were calculated using Equations (1)–(5): C 3 H 6 conversion ( % ) = mol of ( C 3 + 2 3 AA + 1 3 CO 2 ) mol of C 3 H 6 × 100 % (1). PO selectivity ( % ) = mole of PO mol of ( C 3 + 2 3 AA + 1 3 CO 2 ) × 100 % (2). PO formation rate of catalysts ( g PO ∙ kg cat − 1 ∙ h − 1 ) = mole of PO m cat × 58.08 (3). PO formation rate of Au ( g PO ∙ kg Au − 1 ∙ h − 1 ) = mole of PO m Au × 58.08 (4). H 2 Efficiency = mole of PO mole of H 2 conversed × 100 % (5). Where m cat is the mass of catalysts during catalytic testing; C po, C aa, C ao, C al, C pa, C pp, and C co2 refer to the molar flow rate of PO, acetaldehyde, acetone, acrolein, propylaldehyde, propane, and carbon dioxide, respectively. 2.4 Characterizations High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF–STEM, Tecnai G2F 20, United States) was used to investigate the morphology and size distribution of Au nano-particles supported on the surface of TS-1-B. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM: JEOL, Talos 200X, FEI, USA) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX: Oxford, Super X, UK) spectroscopy were used to determine the crystal morphology and elemental distribution. XRD patterns were recorded using a diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation at an angle of 5–90◦ with a step size of 0.02°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded using an Escalab 250Xi XPS system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with a monochromatic Al-Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). The photoelectron binding energies were calibrated using the C 1 s contamination line at 284.6 eV. The XPSPEAK Version 4.0 software was used for peak deconvolution. The specific surface area (SSA) and pore size distribution (PSD) of catalyst samples were obtained using N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K and collected with an ASAP2010 gas-adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics) via the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. Volume fractal dimensions of the mesopores were calculated according to a method reported by Bu et al. [35] and He et al. [36] as described in the Supporting Information. 29Si Solid-state NMR spectra were carried out on a Bruker 400 M NMR spectrometer. The test conditions were as follows: 6.5 μs π/2 pulse, 4 s relaxation delay, 10 kHz spinning rate, and 820 acquisitions. The temperature-programmed ammonia desorption (NH3-TPD) test was conducted using the AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA). Briefly, about 0.1 g sample was loaded in a tube and treated at a temperature of 200 °C for 2 h with a He flow of 50 mL/min. Then the tube was cooled down to 50 °C, and NH3/He purge gas was set at 50 mL/min ( 5 vol% of NH3) for 60 min. Subsequently, the sample was heated to 100 °C to remove all traces of the physically adsorbed NH3, and then heated at a rate of 10 °C/min to 900 °C under He flow of 50 mL/min. Exhaust gases were analyzed by a mass spectrometer (DECRA, HIDEN, UK), and the NH3 desorption signal of m/z = 17 were recorded. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of H2 thermal treatment on the catalytic performance with different Au loading The changes in the DEP reaction performance of prepared Au/TS-1-B catalysts with or without H2 thermal treatment are presented in Fig. 1 along with a comparison of the influence of Au loading. The propylene conversion increased with an increase in the Au loading regardless of whether the catalysts were thermally treated in H2 or not. The differences were relatively insignificant (Fig. 1(a)). In contrast, the difference in PO selectivity was more pronounced in both cases with and without H2 pretreatment (Fig. 1(b)). As a bifunctional catalyst, PO selectivity is affected by the combination of Au components and Ti-Si supports. Generally, the PO selectivity of propylene epoxidation catalyst decreased with an increase in Au loading [37]. The slight increase of PO selectivity using catalyst without treatment in the range of 0.025–0.05 wt.% Au loading should be ascribed to the enhanced oxidation activity due to an increased Au/Ti ratio. The decreased PO selectivity at a higher Au loading indicates the optimization of active components, and their interactions became the dominant factors in limiting the catalytic performance. By comparison, the decrease in the catalyst selectivity was lower when H2 thermal treatment was applied, resulting in the higher selectivity for the catalyst subjected to H2 thermal treatment than that without treatment particularly at a higher Au loading. Therefore, the beneficial effect of H2 thermal treatment can be found in the comparison of PO formation rate, especially when the Au loading was higher than 0.1 wt.% (Fig. 1(c)). The H2 thermal treatment has limited influence on the reaction performance at a low Au loading likely due to the insufficient active sites for the catalytic reaction. With the subsequent increase in Au loading, the positive benefits of H2 thermal treatment in promoting the formation of PO become prominent due to the improvement of specific catalyst properties. In addition, a more significant variation is observed in the composition of DEP reaction by-products with or without H2 thermal treatment of the catalyst (Fig. 1(d)). As the Au loading increased, the proportion of propane in the by-products decreased while the proportion of isomerization products increased, including propionaldehyde, acrolein, and acetone, and the peroxide products, namely acetaldehyde and carbon dioxide. In addition, a lower proportion of propane and a higher proportion of over-oxidation by-products were obtained using the pretreated catalysts, especially in the case of a relatively high Au loading. This indicates that H2 thermal treatment improved the H2 utilization efficiency and the oxidation property of the catalyst [38], which correlates well with the calculated H2 efficiency in Table 1. a: the practical loading refers to the Au addition in the catalyst preparation process; b: the capture efficiency refers to the rate of determined Au content to the added Au content; S c refers to the selectivity; E H 2 refers to the H2 efficiency; DR refers to the deactivation rate. The data of Au/TS-1 and Au/TS-1-H2 were calculated according to Fig. S4. The active metal loading would directly affect their dispersion behavior on the support surface during catalyst preparation. It is generally considered that obtaining Au nanoparticles with tiny and uniform particle sizes is crucial for enhanced DEP reaction performance. Fig. 2 shows the differences in the sizes of the active components on the catalyst with and without H2 thermal treatment under different Au loading. As for the fresh catalyst with an Au loading of less than 0.1 wt.%, the quantity of Au sol loaded on the support surface was limited and the particle size was tiny, which makes it difficult to effectively statistically analyze the particle size distribution in Fig. 2(a) and (b)). The surface elemental mapping results show that the Au component was almost uniformly distributed on the support surface with an Au loading of less than 0.1 wt.% (Fig. S1). After H2 thermal treatment, the even distribution of partial Au sols was evident, indicating an increasing trend of particle size during the process (Fig. 2(e) and (f)). The particle size distributions of Au components loaded onto the support surface before and after H2 treatment under relatively high loading were also compared, displaying a 9.1% and 10% increase in the average particle size after treatment for the 0.1 wt.% (Fig. 2(c) and (g)) and 0.2 wt.% loaded Au/TS-1-B catalyst (Fig. 2(d) and (h)), respectively. Overall, there is a trend toward increasing particle size distribution. Hence, the nano-sized Au sols partially coalesced following H2 thermal treatment, the tendency of which became more pronounced at higher Au loading. This observation is further substantiated by the findings presented in Fig. S2. Reported literature has shown that excessively small or large Au particle sizes are not conducive to DEP reactions, and the formation of propane would be promoted if the particle size is smaller than 2 nm or larger than 5 nm [39]. As for the Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst, the proportion of Au nanoparticles in the range of 2 − 5 nm increased after H2 thermal pretreatment (Fig. 2(g)), which might be the fundamental reason for its higher PO selectivity and PO generation rate. On the other hand, the proportion of propane in the by-products also decreased significantly (Fig. 1(d)). The DEP reaction performance using catalyst with an Au loading beyond 0.1 wt.% did not improve by much. Further increase in the Au loading resulted in a significantly reduced rate of PO formation per unit of Au (Fig. S3). Given the apparent effect of H2 thermal treatment on Au/TS-1-B at a 0.1 wt.% Au loading, the subsequent discussion mainly focuses on the Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic performance changes of DEP catalyst with different pretreatment temperature The effect of H2 thermal treatment temperature on the activity and stability of the catalyst for DEP reactions at 220 °C was further investigated, the results of which are shown in Fig. 3. Following H2 pretreatment at between 250 and 350 °C, the catalysts exhibited a rapid initial increase in the transient PO formation rate during the continuous DEP reaction, which gradually decreased over time (Fig. 3(a)), similar to the reported literature[15]. Overall, following pretreatment at 250 and 300 °C, the rate of catalyst activity increase was slightly lower, but the stability became significantly better than that of the catalyst pretreated at 350 °C. The PO formation rate of the 350 °C-pretreated catalyst decreased by over 25% within 40 h relative to the catalysts pretreated at a lower temperature, which retained a relatively stable performance. Fig. 3(b) displays the improvement in the selectivity of by-products with an increase in the pretreatment temperature, especially above 300 °C. The distribution of each by-product fluctuated slightly upon increasing the pretreatment temperature from 250 to 300 °C. In contrast, following pretreatment at 350 °C, the proportions of propane and acrolein in the by-products decreased to less than 7% and 6% (Table S1), respectively, while the proportion of propionaldehyde quickly rose to more than 46%. Fig. 3(c) displays the temperature dependent catalyst activation time and reaction deactivation rate (see calculation formulas in supporting information). It is clear that the increase in the pretreatment temperature shortened the activation time and allowed the catalyst reaction performance to peak more quickly. However, the deactivation rate of the catalyst is significantly promoted at higher treatment temperature. The deactivation rate of the Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst following 350 °C pretreatment in H2 could reach nearly 5 times that of the catalyst pretreated at 300 °C. The advantage of H2 pretreatment at 300 °C can be confirmed by comparing the catalysts' average PO selectivity and PO formation rate during the DEP reaction (Fig. 3(d)). Therefore, upon considering the reaction performance and stability results, the best temperature for H2 pretreatment was 300 °C. As a noble metal catalyst, both the utilization efficiency of Au in terms of capture rate in catalyst preparation and the catalytic performance of each unit mass of Au during the reactions, along with the ultimate catalyst stability are all critical to determine whether the catalyst can be continuously optimized to suit the practical needs of industrial applications. The DEP reaction performance of the Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst made via sol immobilization method employing NaBH4 is summarized in Table 1 in comparison to the other reported catalysts. The Au capture efficiency of nearly 100% enabled using this preparation method appears to be much higher than that of the deposition precipitation method [Au/TS-1(121)Cs, DPU-Au/TS-1-B, Au/TS-1-urea, etc.], because the reduced Au sol with negative surface charges could readily adsorb onto the surface of TS-1-B supports doped with TPAOH. This could be confirmed by the sharp decrease of zeta potential difference between Au sols and supports containing TPA+ (Table S2). The prepared Au/TS-1-B catalyst via NaHB4 reduction method also displayed a relatively low deactivation rate during the DEP reactions. The prepared Au/TS-1-B catalyst via NaHB4 reduction method also displayed a relatively low deactivation rate during the DEP reactions, which should be mainly ascribed to the application of TS-1-B support. Compared with the catalyst prepared by SI method [Au/TS-1-IL, SEI-Au/TS-1, Au/TS-1PT, etc.], our prepared catalyst exhibits a mainstream performance at a relatively low Au loading, resulting in a superior PO formation rate (80.8 gPO h−1 gAu −1). Though the Au/TS-1-B catalyst has not displayed superiorities in all aspects compared with the listed catalysts, the features of high Au capture efficiency, favorable catalytic stability, and further optimization potentials make the Au/TS-1-B catalyst prepared by NaBH4 method to be a promising catalyst in DEP reactions. The significant effect of H2 treatment on the reaction performance led us to further explore the structural and surface-property evolution of the active metal on the catalyst and the support itself during the H2 thermal pretreatment and the DEP reaction process. 3.3 Geometrical and electronic structure variations of active components The morphology changes of Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst with and without H2 thermal treatment, and the corresponding catalysts after DEP reactions are displayed in Fig. 4. The Au sols were well-dispersed on the surface of TS-1-B support before and after the H2 thermal treatment (Fig. 4(a–b)). The protection of PVP coating would postpone the Au nanoparticle aggregation process under the thermal condition. Organic templates (TPAOH) closed to the external surfaces of TS-1-B supports could be partially decomposed or removed at 200–300 °C [49,50], as proved in the thermal analysis in Fig. S5. This would promote the anchoring effect of exposure support surfaces to the Au nanoparticles and thereby also confine the growth rate of Au nanoparticle. After H2 thermal treatment, the presence of the Au(111) facet can be seen according to the HRTEM images (Fig. 4b), indicating an enhanced crystallinity of Au nanoparticle at the H2 atmosphere, similar to the Au morphology variations in the reducing atmosphere as reported in the literature [51,52]. The sizes of Au nanoparticles on the surface of TS-1-B were enlarged after DEP reactions regardless of whether the spent catalyst was pretreated in H2 or not (Fig. 4(c) and (d)), which might be ascribed to the weakened PVP coatings for stabilizing the metal components [53,54] under a prolonged thermal environment with flow atmosphere. In addition, the larger Au nanoparticles with higher variance appeared in the control group without H2 pretreatment. This should be a fundamental reason for the rapid decrease in PO selectivity for the catalyst without pretreatment in the later stage of DEP reactions. The possible role of H2 thermal treatment on the changes of Au/TS-1-B surface are displayed in Fig. 4(e). Fig. 5 shows the variations of N and O species on the surface of Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst before and after the H2 thermal treatment. The peak intensity of N components significantly decreased during the pretreatment and the further reaction stage, which could also be confirmed by the variations of elemental contents in Table S3 and Table S4. In addition, the decreased proportion of Pyrrole-N and CO species on the surface of H2-treated catalyst is observed in Fig. 5(a) and (b), indicating the simultaneous reduction of PVP together with the TPAOH during the H2 thermal treatment process, which could be also confirmed by the decrease in bulk nitrogen content (Table S4). The Au and Ti distributions on the surface of Au(0.1)/TS-1-B catalyst at different stages are compared in Fig. 6. Experimental results clearly show the increasing peak intensity of Au and Ti components on the surfaces of catalyst in the following order: fresh catalyst, H2-pretreated catalyst, and the spent catalyst. This should be ascribed to the thinning PVP coating for the Au components and the decreasing of TPAOH on the external surface of Ti-Si framework structures. Most of the Au species on the surface of the fresh catalyst existed as the reduced Au (Fig. 6(a)) because of the reduction environment during the catalyst preparation. However, partial Au salts might be quickly coated by organic stabilizers before a through reduction, and these unreduced Au components would be released during the pretreatment and reaction process, and thereby results in the presence of Au+ and Au3+ species (Fig. 6(c) and (e)). During the DEP reactions, the coexistence of disproportionated reaction (from Au+ to Au3+ and Au0) and reduction reaction (from Aun+ to Au0) would produce more Au0 species in the catalyst [30,55]. Considering the Au0 species is the most core-active species for the activation of H2 and O2 relative to the other Au species (Au+ and Au3+), the gradual increase of active Au0 species should be the primary reason for the existence of activation stage in DEP reactions. The H2 thermal treatment could accelerate the above process and thus displayed a lowered activation time (Fig. 3(e)). In addition, the increasing amount of framework Ti (Ti4+) at 485.5 − 459.1 eV [56] displayed in Fig. 6(b), (d), and (f) also exerts a positive effect towards maintaining a steady reaction performance. The exposure of Ti active sites and the evolution of Au nanoparticles in geometrical and electronic structures may influence the interactions between Au and Ti species. This could be deduced from the lowest Au0 binding energy of the catalyst after H2 thermal treatment, most likely because of the electron-donating effect of Ti species in TS-1-B support, indicating an enhanced Au-Ti electronic interaction, which manifested into weak O2 adsorption and beneficial for the DEP reactions [46,57]. 3.4 Pore configuration and surface property changes The surface properties of the TS-1-B support, such as pore structure, acidity, and hydrophobicity may significantly affect its DEP reaction performance. The molecular sieve channels of the TS-1-B were mainly blocked because the contained templates were not calcined. After loading the active Au components, the surfaces of TS-1-B may be partially covered, and further H2 thermal treatment would produce more complexity in the pore structures because of the volatilization or decomposition of the surface TPAOH and PVP. The N2 isotherms of TS-1-B support and fresh and H2-treated catalysts showed the characteristics of Type IV IUPAC isotherm with type H3 or H4 hysteresis loops ( Fig. 7(a)), indicating the existence of irregular mesopores or voids with a narrow slit-like shape [58]. The respective pore size distribution profiles for these 3 catalysts shown in Fig. 7(b) reveal that the support and the catalysts before and after H2 thermal treatment contained a mixture of micropores and mesopores, displaying a feature of hierarchical porous structure [59]. The proportion of micropores nonetheless increased after H2 treatment, which correlates with the significant increase in the specific surface area of the catalyst from 16.7 to 58.4 cm3/g (Fig. 7(c)). The fractal dimensions D 1 and D 2 were reported to reflect the pore surface roughness and pore-structure complexity, respectively [36,60]. As shown in Fig. 7(d) and Table S5, the loading of Au sols on the TS-1-B supports resulted in a lower value of D 1 and D 2, indicating an increased covering effect over the surface pore structures. In contrast, applying thermal H2 treatment on the catalyst likely removed some TPAOH molecules inside the micropores that were closed to the external surfaces. Besides, the changes of Au nanoparticles on the surface of TS-1-B would also lead to a more complex surface morphology. Thereby, the pretreated catalyst exhibited a relatively irregular pore structure (higher D 2) with an uneven surface (higher D 1), which would facilitate the contact of active sites with reactants. The X-ray patterns of TS-1-B support, fresh catalyst, and the H2-treated catalyst are compared in Fig. 8(a), which all display a highly crystalline TS-1 zeolite with MFI-type structure. It is reported that the removal of TPAOH inside the pore structure of TS-1 affect the relative intensities of the crystal planes of (101) and (501), and a greater I (101)/I (501)) contributes to the adsorption of propylene [62]. The increased trend of I (101)/I (501) ratio for the fresh catalyst after H2 thermal treatment indicated an enhanced activity for propylene epoxidation. 29Si NMR spectra were also conducted for studying the Si specie variations, as shown in Fig. 8(b) and (d). The reflection around –116 ppm was ascribed to the orthorhombic symmetry of zeolite (Ti-O-Si), which show little changes between the fresh and H2-treated catalyst, similar to the result in Fig. 6. In contrast, the percentage of hydrophilic Si(OSi)3OH) groups at –103 ppm (Q3) and hydrophobic Si(OSi)4 groups at –113 ppm (Q4) shows a noticeable difference before and after the H2 thermal treatment. An increased value of Q4/Q3 for the H2-treated catalyst means a higher hydrophobicity [63,64], aligned with the XRD analysis, which is conducive to the adsorption of propylene and the desorption of PO [65]. A high partial propylene oxide (PO) pressure would inhibit the propylene epoxidation reaction [66]. The increase in surface hydrophobicity would thus promote the progress of the epoxidation reaction under the same conditions, consistent with the increased proportion of PO and over-oxidation by-products in Fig. 1. The NH3-TPD-MS profile changes in Fig. 8(c) reveal less amount of surface acid sites for catalyst subjected to H2 thermal treatment. A lowered acid sites in the catalyst would diminish the occurrence of side reactions like ring opening and further isomerization reactions [61,67], which might be a critical reason for increased PO selectivity as well as decreased deactivation rate in the DEP reactions by using H2-treated catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have prepared a DEP catalyst with almost complete Au capture efficiency via the NaBH4 reduction method and revealed the beneficial effect of H2 thermal treatment on promoting the catalytic performance. The TS-1-B catalyst with 0.1 wt.% Au loading pretreated at 300 °C under a hydrogen atmosphere achieved a relatively stable PO formation rate of ∼80.8 gPO·h−1·kgAu −1, outperforming the untreated catalyst in activation time and inactivation rate. During the H2 thermal treatment process, the partial decomposition of organic template agents and PVP on the surface of supports and Au nanoparticles occur, which increases the active sites of Au and Ti and enhances their interaction. In addition, the increased pore structure, improved hydrophobicity, and decreased surface acidity for the H2-treated catalyst also contribute to an increased reaction efficiency and stability. The insights given here are essential for the rational design of high-performance Au-containing DEP catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Stable and efficient Au-supported titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1) catalysts are essential for the direct epoxidation of propylene (DEP) using O2 and H2. But the deposition-precipitation method for Au/TS-1 contains low Au capture efficiency and rapid deactivation rate. Herein, Au/TS-1-B (uncalcined TS-1) catalysts were synthesized through a NaBH4 reduction method. The impact of H2-thermal-pretreatment on DEP activities was studied. H2-pretreatment can enhance propylene oxide selectivity, shorten activation time and reduce deactivation rate of catalyst. Organic-templates on the surface of TS-1-B and stabilizers coated on Au-nanoparticles can be partially removed under H2-treatment, thus exposing more active sites for Au and Ti and facilitating their interactions. Furthermore, more porous structures with reduced acid sites and enhanced surface hydrophobicity of pretreated catalyst can promote DEP reaction. Solid stability in TS-1-B, high Au utilization resulting from the reduction method, and favorable modifications through H2-thermal treatment contribute to the exploration of more robust DEP catalyst performance.
coredata.dc:title: Uncalcined TS-1 supported Au catalyst via NaBH4 reduction method for propylene epoxidation: Insights into the H2 pretreatment effect on catalytic performance
